* If a directory named "filename" is found and it contains a file named "filename.cr" directly underneath it, it is required.
* If a file named "filename.cr" is found in the require path, it is required.
* If a file named "filename.cr" is found relative to the current file, it is required.
* It has a type * It can respond to some methods
* Otherwise a compile-time error is issued.
* Parameter names should be *italicized* (surrounded with single asterisks `*` or underscores `_`):
* Text blocks, for example to show program output, must be surrounded with triple backticks followed by the "text" keyword.
* The documentation of a method is included into the method summary and the method details.
* The number of arguments * The type restrictions applied to arguments * Whether the method accepts a [block](blocks_and_procs.html) or not
* To automatically link to methods in other types, do `OtherType#method(arg1, arg2)` or just `OtherType#method`, and enclose it with single backticks.
* To automatically link to methods of the currently documented type, use a hash like `#horns` or `#index(char)`, and enclose it with single backticks.
* To automatically link to other types, enclose them with single backticks.
* To show the value of an expression inside code blocks, use `#=>`.
* Use [standard coding style](coding_style.md) so your project will be navigable and readable to others.
* Use `:nodoc:` to hide public declarations from the generated documentation.
* Use `ditto` to use the same comment as in the previous declaration.
* Use the third person: `Returns the number of horns this unicorn has` instead of `Return the number of horns this unicorn has`.

* We create a `.o` file in the target system and from that file we create a compile.
* Write [documentation](documenting_code.md) to express purpose of your code and support the `crystal doc` generator.

* You can easily create strings with embedded content, known as string interpolation.

* `MyBox.new(value)` delegates to `initialize(@value : T)` * `T` doesn't exist, so it's used as a free var * Because `MyBox` is actually `MyBox(T)`, and `T` is both a free variable and a type argument, `T` becomes the type of the passed value

* `MyBox.new(value)` ã¯å‡¦ç†ã‚’ `initialize(@value : T)` ã«å§”è­²ã™ã‚‹ * `T` ãŒå­˜åœ¨ã—ãªã„ãŸã‚ã€è‡ªç”±å¤‰æ•°ã¨ã—ã¦æ‰±ã‚ã‚Œã‚‹ * `MyBox` ã¯å®Ÿéš›ã¯ `MyBox(T)` ã§ã‚ã‚Šã€`T` ã¯è‡ªç”±å¤‰æ•°ã§ã‚ã‚Šå‹å¼•æ•°ã§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã€`T` ã¯æ¸¡ã•ã‚ŒãŸå€¤ã®å‹ã«ãªã‚‹
* `NoReturn`: similar to `Void`, but the compiler understands that no code can be executed after that invocation.
* `Void`: the absence of a return value.
* `extended` will be invoked at compile-time when a module is extended.
* `included` will be invoked at compile-time when a module is included.
* `inherited` will be invoked at compile-time when a subclass is defined.
* `method_missing` will be invoked at compile-time when a method is not found.
* `require "./foo/bar/baz"` will lookup "foo/bar/baz.cr" or "foo/bar/baz/baz.cr" relative to the current file.
* `require "foo/*"` will require all ".cr" files below the "foo" directory, but not below directories inside "foo".
* `require "foo/**"` will require all ".cr" files below the "foo" directory, and below directories inside "foo", recursively.
* `require "foo/bar/baz"` will lookup "foo/bar/baz.cr" or "foo/bar/baz/baz.cr" in the require path.

<g1>x</g1>: extended whitespace matching (<g2>PCRE_EXTENDED</g2>): Most white space characters in the pattern are totally ignored except when ignore or inside a character class.

`break` and `next` can also be used inside an `until`.
`break` and `next` can't be used inside a captured block.
`break` can also accept arguments: these become the method's return value.
`class` is also useful for creating arrays and collections of class type:
`class` is used to refer to a class type, instead of an instance type.
`ensure` clauses are usually used for clean up, freeing resources, etc.
`return` can be used and will exit from the block (not the surrounding method).
`self` can be used in the type grammar to denote a `self` type.
`typeof` is allowed in the type grammar.
